ef5a029e8ca36ec19cc699fc5d9b3c3090638912.commitMessage:
Ensure afters are invoked if exception is thrown by test or a before

before: @BeforeEach method, BeforeEachCallback, BeforeTestExecutionCallback

after:  @AfterEach method, AfterEachCallback, AfterTestExecutionCallback

Prior to this commit, if an exception was thrown by a test method or a
"before", then "afters" were never invoked, which is in strict contrast
to the semantics of JUnit 4 and other frameworks.

This commit fixes this problem by ensuring that "afters" (for the
appropriate nesting level) are invoked even if the test method or a
"before" throws an exception.

Fixes: #357

65e0bd5483c8923393fa85955ddaf24d68fd8042.commitMessage:
Apply InstancePostProcessor extensions for every test instance

Prior to this commit, InstancePostProcessor extensions were only applied
during the execution of a MethodTestDescriptor instead of at the point
when such an instance was physically instantiated. Consequently,
InstancePostProcessor extensions were never applied to instances of
outer classes when test methods in a nested class were executed, which
lead to improperly initialized outer instances (e.g,
NullPointerExceptions, etc.).

This commit fixes this bug by relocating the invocation of
InstancePostProcessor extensions to places in the framework where test
instances are physically instantiated (i.e., in ClassTestDescriptor and
NestedClassTestDescriptor).

Furthermore, the argument list for the postProcessTestInstance() method
in the InstancePostProcessor API has been modified to accept the test
instance and a generic ExtensionContext.

Issue: #252

b2ba6b95138382f25ca757a5ca2a7295bee4c3b8.commitMessage:
Do not mix execution of extensions and user code

This commit separates the execution of extensions and user code with
regard to test lifecycle callbacks.

a1eb11673e2b7e69bc0c4c2f5c5b81cf572dfeab.commitMessage:
Mask checked exceptions as unchecked exceptions in ReflectionUtils

Prior to this commit, ReflectionUtils.handleException() wrapped checked
exceptions in a TargetExceptionWrapper (a subclass of RuntimeException).
This forced clients of ReflectionUtils to manually handle unwrapping of
checked exceptions.

This commit introduces a new throwAsRuntimeException() method in
ReflectionUtils which uses a reflective hack (based on generics and type
erasure) that tricks the Java compiler into believing that the thrown
exception is an unchecked exception. This approach allows both checked
and unchecked exceptions to transparently propagate up the call stack
without forcing callers to explicitly handle checked exceptions. In
addition, this approach avoids the need to wrap/unwrap checked
exceptions via the TargetExceptionWrapper.

Furthermore, this commit refactors exception handling code within the
JUnit 5 engine to use the newly introduced ThrowableCollector API for
consistent, simplified tracking of exceptions.

Issue: #64
